events.text: DATE: FEBRUARY 1937
LOCATION: TOKYO, JAPAN
Hiroshi grumbles as he flips through a thick tomb of thin pages with not a single hint about the banana leaf fan.
Hm…
A glance at the stack of books on his desk tells him he’s going to have a long night.
Then, he hears a knock on his door.
Come in.

Hiroshi looks up and stiffens at the sight of the imposing silhouette in the doorway.
Immediately, he’s on his feet and standing alert.
Father.
It is just us, there is no need for that.
Hiroshi swiftly reaches for his chair, pulling it back in offering.
After all that you’ve done for me, it would be wrong not to, [i]sir[/i].
I will not be staying long.
He watches intently as the man he admires approaches, his eyes scanning the pages of the open books.
Let's say I asked you to bring forth a hurricane. Would you be able to do it?
Not yet, sir.
Not yet, hm?

Hiroshi didn’t like the hint of disappointment in his voice. This man had taken him in when his parents died, raised him on good moral values, trained him, disciplined him.
He couldn’t disappoint him.
Yes, but I have discovered clues you might be interested in.
Like a bird on fire, Hiroshi flips rapidly through the books.
And what would that be?
Hidden valleys, [i]sacred[/i] valleys known as ‘beyuls’. It seems that the secrets of the fan and other artifacts are all there.

He flips through another couple pages and points out certain passages, glancing at Father each time. 
Father hums and nods as he receives the information. 
He looks expectantly towards Hiroshi.
But nothing about how to get the fan to work again?
Hiroshi failed to meet his gaze.
No.
The elder man sighs and places a hand firmly on Hiroshi’s shoulder.
Hiroshi continues to glare down at the books, but a firm shake from Father forces him to look up.
Do not seek to impress [i]me[/i]. Seek to become a man that our [i]country[/i] can be proud of.

The stomp of Hiroshi’s foot as he stood at attention resonated throughout the office. 
He nods resolutely.
For the Empire.
For the Empire.

…
His father’s grip on his shoulder tightens.

That being said, we cannot claim to have all the information in the world. 
But we make it our goal to be able to do so.
Suddenly, the elder man leans in close to Hiroshi’s ear.

Do not forget that Japan’s power consists of more than its military.
Expand your reach. Expand our influence. Make Japan proud.

...
Hiroshi stood by the port, looking out over the Pacific.
When he hears multiple footsteps approach from behind, he turns around.
There stood his spies, ready to receive orders.

Track down any and all who know about beyuls.
One of which is Professor Howard Allwright from the USA.
…
Assess his knowledge of beyuls. If it is sufficient, bring him to me, [i]alive[/i].
…
Understood?
Yes, sir.
